l
re
to Mr Secre
t
July 15. 89

page.lettertext:
1589 15 July To M
r
Secretary
It my please y
r
H. in my last of
e 9 of
is moneth, w
ch
I sent
by
M
r
Charles
, I signifyed aswell to
e
L.
of
e Counsell as to
yo
r
H. what asnwere I Rxd from
e
ge
n
rall states
, astouching
those articles w
ch
were sent unto mee, & likewise in
e cause of
Vasseur
to what effect I had delt w
th
e
Counsell of State
who have synce resolved to write unto hir
Ma
ty
& to aunswer
es reasons w
ch
I proposed unto
em, w
ch
I think wilbe don
w
th
in 3 or 4 daies In
e meane season I will seeke
by all delayes to differ theyr
ceeding till I heare from yo
r
H.
M
r
Gilpin
& I have jointly
used those
ticular notes
w
ch
were sent unto mee by my Lord
, & because there are in o
r
opinions
t
w
ch
we fynde by continuall experience in conversa
o
n
among
em divers point
of w
ch
some ar sufficiently
vided
for alredy, some are not practicable among them, & some
oth
r
s
t
will but minister occasyon of Jelousy & suspition
& yet make very little for
e weale & good of
e countrey
I thought under humble correction to rec
o
mend
t
w
ch
we had
ob
s
ved to yo
r
H. consydera
o
n, as also becaus ther ar sondry
oth
r
very requesyt point
to be added besydes, M
r
Gilpin &
I will collect
em togeth
r
as they come to o
r
myndes & send
them unto yo
u
/ I have sent yo
r
H. herew
th
a copye of
e
sentence given at
Utrecht
against
Deventer,
w
ch
is as muche
as I did ever look for at theyr hand
, he ys out of pryson
& gon to
Collenborch
to
Coronell Bax
his cousen germayne
wh
r
of of
Barnevelt
having notice signifiyed this daye to a
s
vaunt
of
e Coronell,
t
he thought
e counte of Collenborch would not
suff
r
such a man as Deventer to sojourne yn his Towne / &
t
yt
were far bett
r
for him to Rx a garrison of English men; w
ch
he
uttered very scuffingly agaynst
e nation & w
th
many malitious
speeches agaynst
e same poore man; whom yt seemeth he will
secute further, yf he can come by any meanes, to lay hand
upon him. How
e state of all thing
stand w
th
S
r
Martin
Schencke
this bearer
M
r
Underwood
who is newly come from
him can certify yo
r
H. he hath lately defeated 3 cornet
of
e Ennemy & taken prisoners 100 men w
th
60 horse /
The Ennemy doth encrease his forces about
Hoesden
& hath
lately taken [yn] the Ile of
Bommel
the Houses of
Brackel
&
Poieroyen
& attempted w
th
flatt bottome boates to passe the
water about
Heerwynen
but was repulsed / Since yt is thought
he ys m
r
ched toward
the house of
Heel.
In
e mean season ther
are letters gon from hens to S
r
M
r
tyn Schenck to lett him
und
r
stand
e daunger, wh
r
in we stand in these quarters.
fol.18v
& to require him to send heth
r
some
t of his forces
for yf
e Ennemy shall have passed
e rivers yt is feared
t
Hoekelem,
Asperen,
Leerdam,
Viannen
& Collenborch
wilbe l os t &
en afterward
places of greater importance.
